source.14d5c72f:
# SF Salaries Exercise 

Welcome to a quick exercise for you to practice your pandas skills! We will be using the [SF Salaries Dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/kaggle/sf-salaries) from Kaggle! Just follow along and complete the tasks outlined in bold below. The tasks will get harder and harder as you go along.
source.7d3ba9dd: ### What is the name of highest paid person (including benefits)?
source.caee396c: ### Use the .info() method to find out how many entries there are.
source.b6a2cf61: ###  What is the highest amount of OvertimePay in the dataset ?
source.a5671175: ### How much does JOSEPH DRISCOLL make (including benefits)?
source.1da5fd76: ### What are the top 5 most common jobs?
source.ea65ba5b: ### What was the average (mean) BasePay of all employees per year? (2011-2014) ?
source.40766d07: ### How many Job Titles were represented by only one person in 2013? (e.g. Job Titles with only one occurence in 2013?)
source.79e5e134: ### How many people have the word Chief in their job title? (This is pretty tricky)
source.ec96e0d7: ### What is the name of lowest paid person (including benefits)? Do you notice something strange about how much he or she is paid?
source.926930d0: ### Bonus: Is there a correlation between length of the Job Title string and Salary?
source.5629649a: ### How many unique job titles are there?
source.8c933ad9: ###  What is the job title of  JOSEPH DRISCOLL ? Note: Use all caps, otherwise you may get an answer that doesn't match up (there is also a lowercase Joseph Driscoll).
source.34db31f5: ### Check the head of the DataFrame.
